pageData.text: In this investigation, you will learn how to use a <button class='glossary-text'>digital multimeter</button>, build an elementary circuit on a breadboard, and measure the <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> and current at various points in the circuit.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation –10 minutes
Activity 1: Reading Resistor Bands - 10 minutes
Activity 2: Resistors in Series - 15 minutes
Activity 3: Resistors in Parallel - 15 minutes
Activity 4: Combined Circuit - 15 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Resistors: Series and Parallel

text: Calculate the overall <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> for combinations of <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> in series and parallel.
Describe the physical basis for resistance.
Demonstrate, using the scientific method, an understanding of circuits by collecting and analyzing data, drawing conclusions, and documenting results.

pageData.text: Some of the cells in the heart are electrically excitable, having a charge difference across the plasma membrane that is easily changed. At rest, the electrical potential is negative on the inside of the membrane. When this charge difference is lost and the inner membrane charge shifts toward positive, the cell is said to be depolarized. Restoration of the charge difference is repolarization. There are two clusters, or nodes, of cells with highly unstable resting potentials that undergo cyclical depolarization and repolarization. They set the pace of heart contractions, or heart rate (HR).

The sinoatrial (SA) node is commonly called the pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical signal for contraction and sets the basic heart rate. If the heart beats too slow (bradycardia) or too fast (tachycardia) it may be necessary to implant a pacemaker. A pacemaker consists of leads, a box, a battery, and a computer. The leads are electrically insulated wires. The leads are very thin and flexible and inserted into chambers on the right side of the heart. The leads are attached to a pacemaker box that contains a battery and a small computer that collects and stores information about the heart rhythm. If the leads sense that the heart has slowed down or missed a beat, the pacemaker will send an electrical impulse to stimulate the heart to restore it to its normal rate.

St Jude Medical pacemaker with ruler by Steven Fruitsmaak is available under CC BY 3.0 at
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:St_Jude_Medical_pacemaker_with_ruler.jpg

pageData.altText: An artificial pacemaker with electrode. The body of the device is about 4 centimeters long, and the electrode measures roughly 58 centimeters.

pageData.text: The conduction of electricity occurs as the result of the concerted movement of charge carriers in materials. For this investigation, we will limit the discussion specifically to two charge carriers: electrons and electron holes.

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Electrons</button> are subatomic particles with a charge of −1.6 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>−19</sup>C that reside (and move) in <button class='glossary-text'>electron clouds</button>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Electron holes</button>, which are not actual particles, are classified as the area previously occupied by an electron and have a charge of +1.6 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>−19</sup>C relative to its local environment in the electron cloud.

pageData.text: The electron clouds of the atoms comprising a material form two distinct electronic energy bands: a and a . In , the valence band overlaps with the conduction band, so electrons are free to move through the conduction band. In , there is an energetic separation, termed a band gap, between the valence and conduction bands, but the energy difference is small. have a large band gaps (see Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Conduction band gap diagram, showing an overlap for metal, a slight gap for a semiconductor, and a larger gap for insulator

pageData.text: If <button class='glossary-text'>electrons</button> are given more energy than the band gap’s, electrons will be excited up to the <button class='glossary-text'>conduction band</button> and be able to generate a current.

, R, is a material’s opposition to the movement of charge carriers. All matter has some resistance to electrical flow measured in terms of the ohm, Ω, which is defined as 1V/A. There are specific electronic devices that are used to reduce voltage in a circuit by converting the electronic energy to heat, referred to as Joule heating.

There are various types of construction, but the ones used in this investigation are called because of their construction. The wire leads enter into the resistor and terminate at a composite material. The composite material is a mixture of carbon dust and ceramic powders. The percentage of the ceramic dust in the resistor determines the resistance of the device. Ceramic is an , impeding the charge carriers to traverse the material from carbon atom to carbon atom. A cross section is shown in Figure 2.
To label the resistance of the resistor, the resistor has colored bands printed on it (see Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A cross section of a composition resistor, labeling the ceramic core, carbon film, nickel cap, lead, and protective lacquer
Figure 3: The brown, gray, red and silver bands stamped on a resistor

pageData.text: The four bands, ABCD, provide the in a scientific notation style: AB × 10C ± D Ω. The first three values are determined by these colors: black = 0, brown = 1; red = 2, orange = 3, yellow = 4, green = 5, blue = 6, violet = 7, gray = 8, and white = 9. The fourth band, or tolerance, is either gold, ±5%, or silver, ±10%.

Electrical circuits are closed loop devices with an , and electronic components (i.e., , , , motors) in order to perform some task. Typically, either a battery or a power supply provides the circuit with the emf to generate current in the circuit.

To simplify the description of a circuit, it is customary to draw the circuit in what is known as a schematic diagram. This diagram shows the major components of a circuit and the way they are connected. Pertinent to this experiment are the following symbols for resistors (see Figure 4) and a voltage source (emf) (see Figure 5).

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Schematic diagram symbol for a resistor showing a horizontal line with zigzags in the center
Figure 5: Schematic diagram symbol for a voltage source showing a plus on the left and minus on the right above v

pageData.text: You can imagine that in a circuit, these components could be put in line one after another. This arrangement is called in <button class='glossary-text'>series</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Schematic of a series circuit with R sub 1 and R sub 2 side by side in the circuit and the emf symbol below

pageData.text: Total for a circuit with a number of in is merely the sum of all the individual resistors.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: R sub total equals sigma R sub 1 plus R sub 2 plus ellipses R sub n

pageData.text: This is derived from using , V = IR, and determining the voltage drop across all resistors. The voltage drop across R1 is IR1, and the voltage drop across R2 is IR2. Solving for the total voltage loss across both resistors gives the following equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 2: V equals I R sub 1 plus I R sub 2 equals I begin paren R sub 1 plus R sub 2 end paren

pageData.text: The other possible case is where a circuit branches into many paths, each having a resistor. This arrangement is called in <button class='glossary-text'>parallel</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Schematic of an in parallel circuit, with R sub 1 above and parallel to R sub 2 and the emf symbol below

pageData.text: Total for a circuit with several in is merely the inverse of the inverse sum of the resistors.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: Begin fraction 1 over R sub total end fraction equals sigma begin fraction 1 over R sub 1 end fraction plus begin fraction 1 over R sub 2 end fraction plus ellipses begin fraction 1 over R sub n end fraction

pageData.text: This too is derived from using . The current will take the path of least resistance (the resistor with the lowest resistance), so the current through each resistor is different, but the charge must be conserved. Therefore:

pageData.altText: Equation 4: I equals I sub 1 plus I sub 2 equals begin fraction V over R sub 1 end fraction plus begin fraction V over R sub 2 end fraction equals V begin paren begin fraction 1 over R sub 1 end fraction plus begin fraction 1 over R sub 2 end fraction end paren equals begin fraction V over R sub total end fraction

pageData.text: In these elementary circuits, it is easy to reduce a circuit of several resistors in both arrangements to a single resistor of calculated resistance.

imageData.altText: Figure 6: A circuit schematic made up of one loop. A capacitor labeled V is connected to two resistors in series, labeled R1 and R2, respectively.

pageData.question: The resistors in the image below are in series. R1 = 10 Ω and R2 = 15 Ω. What is the total resistance of this circuit?

imageData.altText: Figure 7: Schematic of an in parallel circuit, with R sub 1 above and parallel to R sub 2 and the emf symbol below

pageData.question: The resistors in the image below are in parallel. R1 = 10 Ω and R2 = 15 Ω. What is the total resistance of this circuit?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: 1 / RTotal = 1 / 10 Ω + 1 / 15 Ω = 5 / 30 Ω RTotal = 6 Ω

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Total resistance for a circuit with a number of resistors in series is merely the sum of all the individual resistors. Total resistance for a circuit with several resistors in parallel is merely the inverse of the inverse sum of the resistors.

img.alt: Equation 1: R sub total equals sigma R sub 1 plus R sub 2 plus ellipses R sub n

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Total resistance for a circuit with a number of resistors in series is merely the sum of all the individual resistors. Total resistance for a circuit with several resistors in parallel is merely the inverse of the inverse sum of the resistors.

img.alt: Equation 1: R sub total equals sigma R sub 1 plus R sub 2 plus ellipses R sub n

pageData.subTitle: The DMM
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>digital multimeter</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>DMM</button>, is an indispensable tool in the electronics laboratory for the measurement of voltage, <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button>, and current. First, plug the black probe into the COM (common) port of the DMM. That probe will always remain in that port no matter what measurement is being made. To measure voltage, resistance, and very small currents (milliampères), the red probe should be plugged into the port labeled VΩmA. Of course, you will need to turn the dial from the OFF setting to the appropriate unit and scale for measure. If your DMM displays the letters OL (overload), you are on the wrong scale and must adjust to the next higher range. If you need to measure currents larger than 200 mA, you need to plug the red probe into the port labeled 10 ADC (10 ampères max, DC). This port runs the measured current through a fuse, so in case the current is too high, the fuse blows instead of the DMM. For measuring voltages and resistances, probe either side of the circuit component(s), or in other words, put the DMM in the circuit in <button class='glossary-text'>parallel</button> with the voltage or resistance you want to measure (the red and black lines represent the colored probes of the DMM).

pageData.subTitle: The Breadboard
pageData.text: The breadboard provided will permit you to “build” your circuit without having to permanently attach the components through soldering.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A resistor with back and red arrows on either side showing the digital multimeter is part of the circuit
Figure 9: Solderless breadboard

pageData.text: The breadboard has many strips of metal (copper usually) that run underneath the board. The metal strips (yellow lines) are laid out as shown below.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: A breadboard with the metal strips in yellow

pageData.text: These strips connect the holes on the top of the board. This makes it easy to connect components together to build circuits. To use the breadboard, the wires of components are placed in the holes (the sockets). The holes are made so that they will hold the component in place. Each hole is connected to one of the metal strips running underneath the board. Basically, those drawn lines over the holes show what holes are connected to one another. Typically, the long top and bottom rows of holes are used for power supply connections. A circuit is built by placing components and connecting them together with wires (your circuit must be a complete loop, with all "lines" connected).

When a path is formed by wires and components from the positive supply node to the negative supply node, we can turn on the power and current flows through the path and the circuit works as connected. Figure 11 shows examples of how connections are made to form <button class='glossary-text'>series</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>parallel</button> circuits.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Two breadboards: one showing connections made to form a series circuit along with its schematic and the other showing connections to form a parallel circuit along with its schematic

A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. In activity 1, you will determine the stated resistance of the resistor using its bands. Then, you will measure the actual resistance using the digital multimeter and calculate the percent difference between the two. You will repeat this for a total for 5 resistors. In activity 2, you will build a circuit with resistors in series, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. Next, you will switch the order of the resistors and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. In activity 3, you will build a circuit with resistors in parallel, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. Then, you will switch the order of the resistors and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. In activity 4, you will build a combined circuit, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors.

Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for the activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Create a work space.
Read through the activities.
Obtain the required materials.

In Activity 1, you will compare the stated <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>resistor</button> determined using the resistor bands with the measured resistance of the resistor using the <button class='glossary-text'>digital multimeter</button> and calculate the percent difference between the two.
Choose all 5 <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> from the equipment kit.

For each resistor, record the color bands, translate that into a , and measure the actual resistance with the DMM. Record all this information in Data Table 1. Be sure that the DMM is set to the correct range based on the expected resistance from the resistor bands.
Calculate how far the actual resistance is from the labeled one using the equation below. Record your calculations in Data Table 1. |(Rmeasured - Rlabeled)/Rlabeled| x 100%

In Activity 2, you will create a circuit with <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> in <button class='glossary-text'>series</button>, calculate the theoretical <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> and measure the actual resistance of the circuit.  You will then switch the positions of the resistors and remeasure the resistance of the circuit.
Choose 3 of the 5 <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> used in Activity 1.
Record the of each (as measured in Activity 1) in the first row of Data Table 2.

Build a circuit with the resistors in . The wire of each resistor will need to terminate in the same row as the next. Figure 12 and Steps 3a through 3c provide an example of how to properly connect them in series. You may choose to use different rows in your circuit.
  1. Resistor 1 is inserted into the breadboard in row 15 and row 23.
  2. Resistor 2 is inserted into a hole in row 23 and row 35.
  3. Resistor 3 is inserted into row 35 and row 41. The first two resistors are connected since they are both in row 23. The last two are connected since they are both plugged into row 35.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: Breadboard showing a circuit as described in Steps 3a through 3c

pageData.text: Calculate Rtotal. Record this value in Data Table 2.

Based upon that measurement, set the DMM to the appropriate range and measure the resistance of the circuit by touching the probes of the DMM on the resistor wires in the beginning and end of the resistor chain (row 15 and row 41 in the Figure 12 example). Record this resistance in Data Table 2.

Swap R1 and R3 in the breadboard. Record the measured resistance of each resistor in row 2 of Data Table 2. Measure Rtotal to prove that the order of the resistors does not affect the total resistance. Record this measurement in Data Table 2.

In Activity 3, you will create a circuit with <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> in <button class='glossary-text'>parallel</button>, calculate the theoretical <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> and measure the actual resistance of the circuit.  You will then switch the positions of the resistors and remeasure the resistance of the circuit.
Use the 3 <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> used in Activity 2.
Record the of each (as measured in Activity 2) in the first row of Data Table 3.

Build a circuit with the resistors in . The wires of all resistors will need to terminate in the same rows. In Figure 13, resistors 1, 2, and 3 are inserted into the breadboard in row 27 and row 39. This is an example of how to properly connect them in parallel. You may choose to use different rows in your circuit.

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Breadboard showing parallel circuit as described in Steps 3

pageData.text: Calculate Rtotal. Record this value in Data Table 3.

Unlike Activity 2, you will need to create contacts for the DMM to measure this parallel arrangement. Plug the black wire into an open slot in the row with the one end of the resistors and the red wire from your kit in a slot in the row of the other ends of the resistors. In Figure 13, the black wire would be inserted into a hole in row 27 and the red in row 39.

Based on the measurement in Step 4, set the DMM to the appropriate range and measure the resistance of the circuit by touching the black probe of the DMM to the black wire and the red probe to the red wire. Record this resistance in Data Table 3.

Swap R1 and R3 in the breadboard. Record the measured resistance of each resistor in row 2 of Data Table 3. Measure Rtotal to prove that the order of the resistors does not affect the total resistance. Record this measurement in Data Table 3.
In Activity 4, you will create a combined circuit with in and in , calculate the theoretical and measure the actual resistance of the circuit.
Use the 5 <button class='glossary-text'>resistors</button> used in Activity 1.
Record the of each (as measured in Activity 1) in Data Table 4.

Build a circuit with R1 leading into a arrangement of R2, R3, R4, and R5 trailing out from those. Figure 14 and Steps 3a through 3c provide an example of how to properly connect them. You may choose to use different rows in your circuit.
  1. R1 is plugged into rows 20 and 25.
  2. R2, R3, and R4 are plugged into rows 25 and 30.
  3. R5 is plugged into rows 30 and 35.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: Schematic of circuit described in Steps 3a through 3c

pageData.text:
Calculate Rtotal. You can do this by reducing this down.
  1. First calculate the resistance of the parallel arrangement of R2, R3, and R4.
  2. That calculated resistance is in to R1 and R5. Record this value in Data Table 4.

Based on the measurement in Step 4, set the DMM to the appropriate range and measure the resistance of the circuit by touching the black probe of the DMM to the ends of R1 and R5. Record this resistance in Data Table 4.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. In activity 1, you will determine the stated resistance of the resistor using its bands. Then, you will measure the actual resistance using the digital multimeter and calculate the percent difference between the two. You will repeat this for a total for 5 resistors. In activity 2, you will build a circuit with resistors in series, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. Next, you will switch the order of the resistors and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. In activity 3, you will build a circuit with resistors in parallel, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. Then, you will switch the order of the resistors and measure the actual resistance of the resistors. In activity 4, you will build a combined circuit, calculate the total resistance and measure the actual resistance of the resistors.

pageData.content: Figure 14. Circuit diagram for a combined circuit
pageData.altText: Figure 14: Schematic of circuit described in Steps 3a through 3c

data.title: Capacitor
data.content: An electrical device that stores charge

data.title: Composition resistor
data.content: The most common resistor;  a resistor composed of a resisting material and a binding material

data.title: Conduction band
data.content: A delocalized band of energy partly filled with electrons in a crystalline solid; these electrons have great mobility and are responsible for electron conductivity

data.title: Conductor
data.content: A material that permits electrons to flow freely from particle to particle; the charge can be transferred across the entire surface of the object

data.title: Digital multimeter (DMM)
data.content: A device used to measure two or more electrical values - principally voltage, current, and resistance

data.title: Electromotive force (emf)
data.content: The electric potential produced by either electrochemical cell or by changing the magnetic field

data.title: Electron
data.content: A fundamental particle that has a negative charge

data.title: Electron cloud
data.content: A system of electrons surrounding the nucleus of an atom

data.title: Electron hole
data.content: The area previously occupied by an electron and have a charge e of +1.6 × 10^ −19C relative to its local environment in the electron cloud

data.title: Insulator
data.content: A material that impedes the free flow of electrons from atom to atom and molecule to molecule

data.title: Ohm's law
data.content: States that the voltage of a circuit is directly proportional to the product of the current and resitance of a circuit

data.title: Parallel
data.content: Describes an electrical circuit in which current flows in more than one path at the same time

data.title: Resistance (R)
data.content: The measure of how much an object opposes the flow of current

data.title: Resistor
data.content: An electronic device used to reduce voltage in a circuit by converting the electrical energy to heat

data.title: Semiconductor
data.content: Any class of solids whose electrical conductivity is between that of a conductor and that of an insulator in being nearly as great as that of a metal at high temperatures and nearly absent at low temperatures

data.title: Series
data.content: Describes an electrical circuit that permits the entire current to travel through all components

data.title: Transistor
data.content: A semiconductor device with three connections that is capable of amplification in addition to rectification

data.title: Valence band
data.content: The band of electron orbitals that electrons can jump out of, moving into the conduction band when excited; the outermost electron orbital of any atom of a specific material that electrons can occupy
